docs.lead_paragraph: After writing a gossip and party column about Hollywood for more than 26 years, George Christy has been removed from his job at The Hollywood Reporter, pending separate investigations by the newspaper and the Screen Actors Guild into allegations that he accepted favors from movie producers and received pension and health benefits for which he was not entitled. Lynda Miller, a spokeswoman for The Reporter, said today that Mr. Christy's column would no longer be published. ''His column has been placed on hold indefinitely while we conduct an internal review and while he is being audited by'' the guild, she said. Executives at the daily trade newspaper said that a brief notice about the suspension of Mr. Christy's column would probably appear on Tuesday and that another feature about Hollywood parties and premieres would replace it.

headline.main: Hollywood Paper Suspends Column by George Christy

docs.abstract: Columnist George Christy has been removed from his job at The Hollywood Reporter, pending separate investigations by newspaper and Screen Actors Guild into allegations that he accepted favors from movie producers and received pension and health benefits for which he was not entitled; Christy worte gossip and party column for more than 26 years; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For the last three years, the federal budget surplus has been a sketch pad for the dreams of politicians, promising progress on an array of initiatives by both parties. But substantial portions of the surplus projected have now been set aside, first for reducing the national debt and then for the tax cut that Congress sent to President Bush today. When the price tags of all the additional programs planned by one party or the other or both are tallied, a funny thing turns out to have happened to the surplus: Even before it materializes, it has been largely parceled out.

headline.main: Still Uncertain, Budget Surplus Is Gobbled Up

docs.abstract: Substantial portions of projected federal budget surplus have now been parceled out to debt relief, tax cuts and other programs, despite some doubt about whether windfall will materialize, given shaky state of economy; Congress, having passed huge tax cut, will have to begin working in earnest after summer on spending bills for next year; showdowns seen on parceling remaining money among multitude of priorities, and tax cut will constrain those choices; surplus over ten years is projected at $5.6 trillion, including $2.5 trillion from excess Social Security revenue that both parties have promised to use only to reduce national debt; Pres Bush's tax cut would use up almost $1.7 trillion, so that only about $1 trillion remains unallocated; Democrats warn something will have to give (M)
docs.snippet: For the last three years, the federal budget surplus has been a sketch pad for the dreams of politicians, promising progress on an array of initiatives by both parties.    But substantial portions of the surplus projected have now been set aside,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Andrea Clair Frank and Frank Joseph Mirkow, were married yesterday by the Rev. Angelo Feldkamp at Holy Name of Jesus Catholic Church in Kimberly, Wis. Mrs. Mirkow, 30, graduated from the University of Wisconsin and is a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at George Washington University. She is the daughter of Carole and Anton Frank of Kimberly. Her father, who is retired, was a buyer for the Service & Supply Company, a wholesale heating and air-conditioning company in Appleton, Wis. Her mother is a secretary at Network Health Plan, an insurance company in Menasha, Wis.

docs.lead_paragraph: After four years on dialysis, with no sign that he was nearing the top of the transplant waiting list, Moshe Tati decided to buy a kidney. This was easier than he had imagined. Several months previous, the name and telephone number of an organ broker had been passed, furtively, around his dialysis group. At the time, Moshe did not think he would use the telephone number. He thought he would wait. Then his health began to fail. This happens with kidney patients. Dialysis is a tricky thing, rough on the body -- it keeps you alive while gradually killing you. It is not uncommon for a person to lose 15 pounds during a single three-hour dialysis session. Shortly before he made his decision to buy, Moshe suffered a heart attack. The attack was minor, but it reduced his suitability for transplant surgery and dropped his standing on the organ-waiting list. He was now placed below some people whose kidney failure had just been diagnosed. Moshe was 43 years old, and he was dying, and not one of his family members was a suitable match for a kidney donation. So he called the broker.

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress gave final approval today to the biggest tax cut in a generation, voting to reduce all income tax rates over the next five years and to give the weakened economy a quick jolt by sending rebates to taxpayers this summer. After days of intense negotiations over how to apportion the tax cut of $1.35 trillion in the next decade -- and a final round of brief but bitter partisan debate during an unusual Saturday morning session -- Republican leaders moved the bill quickly through both House and Senate.

headline.main: Congress Passes Tax Cut, With Rebates This Summer

docs.abstract: Congress gives final approval to $1.35-trillion tax cut over next decade, starting with rebate checks this summer that could give quick jolt to lagging economy; bill passes House, 240-154, and Senate, 58-33; 28 Democrats join all House Republicans and 12 Democratic senators join 46 Republicans; photos; Pres Bush welcomes passage; Democratic leader Sen Tom Daschle 'short-term politics,' and predicts Congress will have to make corrections later; immediate $300-600 rebates and phased-in provisions explained, including gradual cut in federal estate tax and tax rate cut; all provisions end by 2011 unless future Congress re-enacts them (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Russell Andrew Nelson, who led Johns Hopkins Hospital in a period of robust growth in the 1950's and 60's, died last Saturday at a nursing home in Naples, Fla. A former resident of Baltimore, he was 88. Dr. Nelson became director of the hospital in 1952 and president in 1963. Under his administration, Johns Hopkins greatly expanded its physical plant and pioneered comprehensive prepaid health care programs.

headline.main: Russell A. Nelson, 88; Led Johns Hopkins Hospital

docs.abstract: Dr Russell Andrew Nelson, who led Johns Hopkins Hospital during 1950's and 1960's, dies at age 88 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts liberal whom Republicans love to vilify, is planning a swift vote on increasing the minimum wage. Senator Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico wants to limit plans for more oil drilling in Alaska and instead encourage conservation. And Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut has his eye on President Bush's plans to relax rules on arsenic in drinking water, forest roads and mining sludge. Although they are working on short notice -- Democrats learned just Thursday they will take control of the Senate for the first time since 1995 -- the men who are expected to lead the Senate's 15 committees are already busy shaping the year ahead.

headline.main: New Chairmen Shift Priorities For the Senate

docs.lead_paragraph: The Census Bureau each fall goes through a ritual that is as Americana as the World Series. A press conference is convened, and senior officials, illustrating their numbers with colorful charts, disclose to the nation the latest income data. None gets more attention than the poverty level. A family of four that falls below $17,062 in annual income falls into poverty, the bureau declared last September. Federal aid programs indexed to the poverty line -- Head Start, food stamps and children's health insurance, among others -- are then doled out accordingly, which is a lot of power for a statistic that is out of touch with reality.

headline.main: How to Define Poverty? Let Us Count the Ways

docs.abstract: Article explains why poverty line, as annually defined by Census Bureau, is not realistic measure of poverty; income levels are only criterion used, but article contends that more significant data exist to measure deprivation; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Census Bureau each fall goes through a ritual that is as Americana as the World Series. A press conference is convened, and senior officials, illustrating their numbers with colorful charts, disclose to the nation the latest income data. None...

docs.lead_paragraph: Many hospitals are winning sharply higher payments from insurers, and the efforts by insurance companies to pass those costs along to employers and consumers are contributing to the most rapid surge in medical costs in years. Medical costs increased 10 to 15 percent in the first quarter for the biggest insurance companies after averaging 5 to 6 percent for a decade. Experts expect them to keep rising. And health maintenance organizations are asking the employers that are their biggest customers for increases in premiums averaging 18.3 percent, according to a preliminary estimate by Hewitt Associates, with proposed increases as high as 60 percent.

headline.main: Medical Costs Surge as Hospitals Force Insurers to Raise Payments

docs.abstract: Efforts by insurance companies to pass higher hospital costs along to employers and consumers is contributing to most rapid surge in medical costs in years; medical costs increased 10 to 15 percent in first quarter for biggest insurance companies after averaging 5 to 6 percent for decade; health maintenance organizations are asking employers, their biggest customers, for increases in premiums averaging 18.3 percent, with proposed increases as high as 60 percent; hospitals have become more powerful through mergers and acquisitions; they are using their enhanced market power to demand major increases in payments from health insurance companies; some have refused to accept patients covered by insurance companies that have not paid up; many hospitals have not received increase in payments for years, and must contend with their own rising labor costs; in addition, drug costs continue to rise precipitously; graph (M)
